content.body: My understanding at the moment is that a module block corresponds to a `Module` instance, so locally it will only initialize once. But, every time a `Module` gets serialized and deserialized, it emerges as a new `Module` instance on the far side. The only parts of the module instance that are serialized are the `source` and `importMeta`, to the extent that `importMeta` is serializable, and the module instance is not memoized by the receiver.
content.formatted_body: My understanding at the moment is that a module block corresponds to a Module instance, so locally it will only initialize once. But, every time a Module gets serialized and deserialized, it emerges as a new Module instance on the far side. The only parts of the module instance that are serialized are the source and importMeta, to the extent that importMeta is serializable, and the module instance is not memoized by the receiver.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: My understanding at the moment is that a module block corresponds to a `Module` instance, so locally it will only initialize once. But, every time a `Module` gets serialized and deserialized, it emerges as a new `Module` instance on the far side. The only parts of the module instance that are serialized are the `source` and `importMeta`, to the extent that `importMeta` is serializable, and the module instance is not memoized by the receiver.

My understanding at the moment is that a module block corresponds to a Module instance, so locally it will only initialize once. But, every time a Module gets serialized and deserialized, it emerges as a new Module instance on the far side. The only parts of the module instance that are serialized are the source and importMeta, to the extent that importMeta is serializable, and the module instance is not memoized by the receiver.

content.body: And the reasoning for module fragments is that every module fragment has a unique `ModuleSource` consisting of the fragment and all the fragments it transitively depends upon, so each fragment is effectively equivalent to a single module block.

content.body: We may want to think about if we want a generic mechanism to serialize a Module over a ShadowRealm boundary but the answer isn’t “it’s the same one”

I’m also not sure that there’s any meaningful way to distinguish dynamic import of a module from one realm to another. My impression is that using dynamic import to kick off the module system is not much more than a cute way to spell `Module.prototype.importMe`. The module object is important, the `import` “function” doesn’t exist.

content.formatted_body:
consider this code:

// a
import { f_b } from 'b'
console.log(f_b)
export function f_a() {}

// b
import { f_a } from 'a'
console.log(f_a)
export function f_b() {}

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body:
consider this code:

// a
import { f_b } from 'b'
console.log(f_b)
export function f_a() {}

// b
import { f_a } from 'a'
console.log(f_a)
export function f_b() {}

content.formatted_body:
It will be converted to:

const a = {
    bindings: [{ export: "f_a" }, { import: "f_b", from: "b" }],
    initialize(env) {
        function f_a() {}
        env.f_a = f_a
        console.log(env.f_b)
    }
}

const b = {
    bindings: [{ export: "f_b" }, { import: "f_a", from: "a" }],
    initialize(env) {
        function f_b() {}
        env.f_b = f_b
        console.log(env.f_a)
    }
}

content.formatted_body:
In reply to @jackworks:matrix.org

The best I can do using the ThirdPartyModuleRecord is this:

const a = {
    bindings: [{ export: "f_a" }, { import: "f_b", from: "b" }],
    initialize(env) {
        function f_a() {}
        env.f_a = f_a

    bindings: [{ export: "f_b" }, { import: "f_a", from: "a" }],
    initialize(env) {
        function f_b() {}
        env.f_b = f_b
        console.log(env.f_a)
    }
}
This cannot emulate the ES Module above, because it is basically the equivalent of export let f_a = ... instead of export function f_a() ...

content.formatted_body:
And SystemJS format can emulate this behavior:

System.register([
    "b"
], function(_export, _context) {
    "use strict";
    var f_b;
    function f_a() {}
    _export("f_a", f_a);
    return {
        setters: [
            function(_b) {
                f_b = _b.f_b;
            }
        ],
        execute: function() {
            console.log(f_b);
        }
    };
});

There are 2 stages in system js, the hoisted function declaration is set in stage 1, and the actual runtime code is run in stage 2 (execute).

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body:
And SystemJS format can emulate this behavior:

System.register([
    "b"
], function(_export, _context) {
    "use strict";
    var f_b;
    function f_a() {}
    _export("f_a", f_a);
    return {
        setters: [
            function(_b) {
                f_b = _b.f_b;
            }
        ],
        execute: function() {
            console.log(f_b);
        }
    };
});

There are 2 stages in system js, the hoisted function declaration is set in stage 1, and the actual runtime code is run in stage 2 (execute).

content.body: Hm, that’s not quite right. The writer can’t be a property of the static module record.

content.body: But, for one, being able to emulate ESM is a stretch goal for the virtual module record. The subset is sufficient for most cases.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: But, for one, being able to emulate ESM is a stretch goal for the virtual module record. The subset is sufficient for most cases.

content.body: The SES shim has a protocol analogous to SystemJS, though, but calls the setters notifiers.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The SES shim has a protocol analogous to SystemJS, though, but calls the setters notifiers.

content.body: Ah, I see. The trick to supporting ESM with the virtual source module protocol is that all access and mutation to variables in the “imports namespace” needs to be rewritten to properties of the the environment object. I haven’t checked into how realistic that is, but it likely means that all var and function hoisting would have to be physically hoisted.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Ah, I see. The trick to supporting ESM with the virtual source module protocol is that all access and mutation to variables in the “imports namespace” needs to be rewritten to properties of the the environment object. I haven’t checked into how realistic that is, but it likely means that all var and function hoisting would have to be physically hoisted.

content.body: I think it’s possible but not clean.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think it’s possible but not clean.

content.body: In SES, we have a self-imposed requirement that ESM sources need to be debuggable without source maps, with preservation of line numbers and, as often as possible, column numbers. That simply wouldn’t be possible with the virtual source protocol and requires write barriers / notifiers.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: In SES, we have a self-imposed requirement that ESM sources need to be debuggable without source maps, with preservation of line numbers and, as often as possible, column numbers. That simply wouldn’t be possible with the virtual source protocol and requires write barriers / notifiers.
